Daraufhin bereiteten Ost- und Westdeutschland etwa zwei Jahre lang die Bildung einer innerdeutschen Mannschaft vor. Bis zur Olympiade von 1964, die in Tokio ausgetragen wurde, nahmen Ost- und Westdeutschland sechs Mal mit einer gemeinsamen Mannschaft teil.

articles.title: “Peace on the Ice in Korea”
articles.title_sub: North and South Korean women's ice hockey teams unite for Pyeongchang Olympics
articles.result: The North and South Korean unified team won the 500m race for the women’s canoe at the 2018 Asian Games in Jakarta-Palembang.
articles.prints: A single team composed of 52 male and 11 female athletes from East and West Germany competed at the 1956 Winter Olympics in Cortina d'Ampezzo, Italy. It was the first time the two nations competed together on the international scene since the Second World War. East and West Germany walked to Beethoven’s “Ode to Joy” and carried a united flag during the opening ceremonies. The International Olympic Committee (IOC) originally proposed that East Germany, a non-member nation, form a single team with West Germany to participate in the games. Negotiations for the plan to form a single team took about two years to finalize. This inter-German sportsmanship persisted for a handful years until the Tokyo Olympics in 1964, but by then the two had participated together a total of six times.

articles.title: „Eine Eisfläche des Friedens, auf der Nord- und Südkoreaner sich friedlich begegnen.“
articles.title_sub: Bei den Olympischen Spielen in PyeongChang nimmt zum ersten Mal ein vereintes Frauen-Eishockeyteam teil.
articles.result: Bei den Asian Games 2018 in Jakarta und Palembang gewann das innerkoreanische Frauen-Team der Kanufahrerinnen das 500 m-Rennen.
articles.prints:
Das innerkoreanische Eishockey-Team der Frauen bestritt bei der Winterolympiade 2018 in PyeongChang sein erstes Spiel gegen die Schweiz.
 Im Kwandong Icehockey Centre von Gangneung, wo die Wettkämpfe ausgetragen wurden, waren unter anderem der südkoreanische Präsident Moon Jae-In, die erste stellvertretende Vorsitzende des Zentralkomitees Kim Yo-jong, der schweizerische Bundespräsident Alain Berset, der Präsident des Internationalen Olympischen Komitees Thomas Bach und weitere Gäste anwesend und feuerten die teilnehmenden Sportler an.
 Das innerkoreanische Team wurde zwar begeistert angefeuert, zumal es das erste Spiel war, verlor allerdings mit einem großen Punkteunterschied gegen eine starke Schweiz.
 Es war zwar schon vorgekommen, dass Nord- und Südkorea zusammen an internationalen Wettkämpfen, einschließlich der Olympiade teilgenommen hatten, aber es war das erste Mal, dass eine gemeinsame Mannschaft bei den Olympischen Spielen antrat. Abgesehen von Sieg und Niederlage genoss das innerkoreanische Team schon vor diesem Spiel große Aufmerksamkeit der Weltgemeinschaft, und auch wenn es mit einem bedauerlichen Ergebnis endete, ist es der Öffentlichkeit als bedeutendes Spiel in Erinnerung geblieben.

articles.title: "Unification on a Ping-Pong Sized Scale"
articles.title_sub: A Unified North and South Korean women's singles team wins the 41st World Table Tennis Championships
articles.result: At the 2018 Korea Open International Table Tennis Tournament, Chang Woo-jin and Cha Hyo-sim competed together as a unified Korean team and won the championship against China in mixed doubles. The victory of 1991 was repeated again 27 years later.
articles.prints: The unified women's ice hockey team of North and South Korea played their first match against Switzerland at the 2018 Pyeongchang Olympic Games. In attendance of the match at the Gwandong Hockey Center in Gangneung were South Korean President Moon Jae-in, Vice Director of the WPK of North Korea, Kim Yo-jung, Swiss President Alain Berset, and President of the IOC, Thomas Bach. This first game for the unified team drew a lot of attention, but the strong Swiss team easily defeated the Koreans. Even though the two Koreas had walked together several times before, it was the first time they participated in the Olympic Games a sport together. Regardless of the outcomes at the games, their unifying presence captured the attention of the whole world.

articles.title: „Eine kleine Wiedervereinigung für ein Tischtennis-Turnier.“
articles.title_sub: Die Tischtennis-Team, bestehend aus Nord- und Südkoreanerinnen, siegt bei der 41. Tischtennis-Weltmeisterschaft.
articles.result:
Bei der Tischtennis-WM 2018, den Korea Open, traten Jang Woojin und Cha Hyo-Sim als 
Vertreter für Nord- und Südkorea an und gewannen im gemischten Doppel gegen China.
Nach dem Erfolg bei der Tischtennis-WM von 1991 hat die innerkoreanische Mannschaft 
erstmals nach 27 Jahren wieder eine hervorragende Leistung zeigte.
articles.prints:
Bei der 41. Tischtennis-Weltmeisterschaft, die 1991 im japanischen Chiba ausgetragen wurde, trat das innerkoreanische Frauenteam mit Hyun Jung-Hwa aus Südkorea und Rhee Bun-Hee aus Nordkorea an. Dabei besiegten sie im Convention Center vor den Augen der in Japan lebenden Koreaner das stärkste Team der Welt – China – und gewannen die Goldmedaille. China hatte einen Satz gewonnen, und der nordkoreanischen Spielerin Yu Sun-Bok, die vier Punkte zurücklag, gelang eine sensationelle Aufholjagd dank ihrer starken Rückhand.
 So erlangte das vereinte „Team Korea“, das im Zuge des harmonischen innerkoreanischen Sportleraustausches gebildet worden war, 47 Jahre nach der Teilung den Sieg bei einem internationalen Sportturnier.

articles.title: "Stamina, a National Asset"
articles.title_sub: How the East German athletes were trained for the 1988 Summer Olympics
articles.result: The coaches of the East German Olympic team became international celebrities and role models for other teams.
articles.prints: Athletes of the East German National team came in second overall at the 1988 Seoul Olympics. Their success demonstrated the country’s commitment to cultivating talent on a national level. They organized more than 10,000 sport clubs nationwide and established physical education universities in all major cities. Every year, the government would admit three to four thousand students to the College of Physical Education and enroll them in master’s level programs in fields such as anatomy and biomechanics. To ensure international success, the East German government even condonded some forms of doping. The government also felt the need to strengthen its physical education policy to make up for the disadvantage of losing millions of people to the division, so much so that they included a clause in their constitution that demanded the need for sporting communities to cultivate a fully realized socialist personality.

articles.title: „Auch körperliche Fitness ist das Kapital eines Landes.“
articles.title_sub: Die geheimen Methoden, mit denen Ostdeutschland den Sportnachwuchs fördert, werden bei der Olympiade 88 zum Gesprächsthema.
articles.result: Viele ostdeutsche Trainer wurden direkt nach der Wiedervereinigung von ausländischen Mannschaften rekrutiert, und die Methoden, mit denen die DDR sportliche Talente entdeckt und gefördert hat, wurden zum Vorbild für andere Länder.
articles.prints:
Bei der Olympiade 1988 erreichten die Sportler der DDR in Seoul Rang 2 beim Medaillenspiegel.
 Vor allem im Schwimmen und in der Leichtathletik zeigten die Ostdeutschen eine starke Leistung und stellten Rekorde auf. Das war das Ergebnis einer disziplinierten, staatlich betriebenen Nachwuchsförderung von sportlichen Talenten.
 Das sportliche Leben in ganz Ostdeutschland war in über 10.000 Sportvereinen organisiert, und in Großstädten wurden Sporthochschulen gegründet und straff geführt. Jedes Jahr schrieben sich 3.000 bis 4.000 Studenten an den Sporthochschulen ein und erlernten Fachwissen über Anatomie und Biodynamik, auf dem Nideau eines Masterprogrammes. Nachdem sie sich in ihrer besten Disziplin trainiert hatten, traten sie bei internationalen Wettkämpfen an und erreichten hohe Platzierungen. Um international anerkannt zu werden, schreckte die ostdeutsche Regierung auch nicht davor zurück, ihren Sportlern Dopingmittel in den verschiedensten Formen zu verabreichen.
 Nach der Teilung von Ost und West war die DDR mit 17 Millionen Einwohnern zahlenmäßig unterlegen, und um eine Aufholjagd zu starten, förderte sie ein starkes Bewusstsein für den Sport. Selbst in ihrer Verfassung stand, dass man die sportlichen Aktivitäten der Bürger fördern muss, damit sie die sozialistische Ideologie vollkommen verinnerlichen können.

articles.title: "Clash of the Two Koreas"
articles.title_sub: With 50,000 spectators, North and South Korean sister teams tie
articles.result: South Korea ended the stage with three wins and one draw and were ranked number one in their group. North Korea also recorded three wins and one draw, but failed to advance to the finals due to a point difference.
articles.prints: The North and South Korean women’s football teams played each other at the women’s Asian Cup quarterfinals on April 7th, 2017. It was the 16th A-match and was held at the Kim Il-sung Stadium in Pyongyang. The South Korean team had to defeat the North Koreans at home in order to advance to semi-finals and qualify for the World Cup. Meanwhile, the North Korean team was aiming to score multiple goals to secure a victory and a chance for the World Cup. 50,000 spectators crowded the stadium an hour before kickoff, anxiously awaiting the action. North Korea came out on top in the first half, but the South Koreans responded with a goal in the second half, finishing the game in a tie. In total, the South Korean football team has 1 win, 3 draws, and 14 losses against the North Korean team.

articles.title: „Die Frauen-Fußballteams aus Nord- und Südkorea treffen in Pyöngyang aufeinander.“
articles.title_sub: Das Spiel, das vor den Augen von 50.000 Zuschauern stattfindet, endet mit einem Unentschieden.
articles.result:
Südkorea gewann drei Mal, spielte ein Mal unentschieden, rückte so auf den Platz des Gruppenersten und kam ins Finale.
Auch Nordkorea gewann drei Mal und spielte ein Mal unentschieden, schaffte es aber wegen eines großen Punkteunterschieds nicht, sich fürs Finale zu qualifizieren.
articles.prints:
Am 7. April 2017 trafen die südkoreanische Fußballnationalmannschaft der Frauen und die nordkoreanische Nationalmannschaft, die beide zu Gruppe B gehörten, für ein Qualifikationsspiel für den Asia Cup 2018 in der Vorrunde aufeinander.
 Es war das 16. Internationale Match, wurde im Kim Il-sung-Stadion ausgetragen und war ein historisches Auswärtsspiel. Südkorea musste Nordkorea schlagen und den Rang des Gruppenersten belegen, um sich für das Finale des Asian Cups und gleichzeitig für die Frauen-WM zu qualifizieren, und Nordkorea musste die Auswärtstorregel anwenden, um sich den Sieg zu sichern.
 Schon eine Stunde vor Spielbeginn waren 50.000 Zuschauer ins Stadion geströmt und feuerten die Spieler begeistert an.
 Dann schoss Nordkorea in der ersten Hälfte, und Südkorea in der zweiten Hälfte je ein Tor, und das Spiel endete mit einem Unentschieden. So kam es für die südkoreanische Frauenfußballmannschaft zur folgenden Spielbilanz bei den Begegnungen mit ihren nordkoreanischen Gegnerinnen: Ein Sieg, drei Mal unentschieden und vierzehn Niederlagen.

articles.title: "A Peaceful March Under a Unified Flag"
articles.title_sub: North and South Korea walk together at the Pyeongchang Olympics
articles.result: The two Koreas joint participation demonstrated the true Olympic spirit of peace and harmony and rendered the Pyeongchang Winter Olympics the Peace Olympics.
articles.prints: After 11 years of no public contact, the North and South Korean Olympic teams made a joint entry at the opening ceremony of the 2018 winter games. February 9th, 2018 marked the special occasion at the Olympic Stadium in Pyeongchang, in the Gangwon Province of Korea. Several high-level inter-Korean talks took place to organize and publicize the magnitude of this historic reconciliation.

articles.title: „Friedlicher Einmarsch unter vereinter koreanischer Flagge.“
articles.title_sub: Nord- und südkoreanische Athleten laufen bei der Eröffnung der Olympischen Winterspiele in PyeongChang gemeinsam ins Stadion ein.
articles.result: Durch die Teilnahme Nordkoreas, die Bildung einer innerkoreanischen Mannschaft und den gemeinsamen Einlauf der Athleten demonstrierten die zwei Länder den olympischen Geist von Frieden und Eintracht. So verwandelten sie die Athleten die Winterolympiade von PyeongChang zur Olympiade des Friedens.
articles.prints:
Bei der Eröffnungszeremonie zur Winterolympiade 2018, die am 9. Februar in Pyeongchang stattfand, liefen süd- und nordkoreanische Sportler nach elf Jahren wieder gemeinsam und unter einer gemeinsamen Flagge ins olympische Stadion ein. 
 Bei den Gesprächen, die in mehreren Runden zwischen hochrangigen nord- und südkoreanischen Entscheidungsträgern geführt wurden, wurde beschlossen, dass die Spieler aus beiden Ländern als vereinte Mannschaft an der Olympiade teilnehmen, was eine absolute Premiere in der Geschichte der Olympischen Spiele war.
 Die ganze koreanische Halbinsel umwehte eine versöhnliche Stimmung, und dies wurde dank der Olympiade auch der ganzen Welt vermittelt, sodass die Erwartungen an einen lebendigen innerkoreanischen Austausch hoch waren.

articles.title: "Hungary, Romania, Bulgaria"
articles.title_sub: Dorothea Ebert, a violinist who fled to pursue her dreams
articles.result: At the 25th anniversary of the fall of the Berlin Wall on November 9th, 2014, Dorothea Ebert performed the Bach concerto she practiced by imaginition during her time in prison.
articles.prints: Dorothea Ebert, who dreamed of becoming a violin soloist, attempted her escape in 1983 on the Bulgarian and Yugoslavian border. She was caught, arrested, and extradited to East Germany and sentenced to two years and eight months in prison. She tried to flee through Hungary and Romania to get to Bulgaria, but ultimately failed in her attempt to escape from the East German regime. She found it increasingly difficult to accept the East German government’s intervention in her life. For example, despite her excellent academic record and talent, she was expected to become a music teacher, not a concert soloist. Fed up, she and her brother decided to flee, but were caught and persecuted. In December 1984, the West German government paid ransom for their release and allowed them to settle West Germany.

articles.title: „Von Ungarn nach Rumänien, dann wieder nach Bulgarien… verzweifelte Flucht.“
articles.title_sub: Die Geigerin Dorothea Ebert flieht für die Verwirklichung ihres Traums über Landesgrenzen.
articles.result: Am 9. November 2014 – 25 Jahre nach dem Fall der Berliner Mauer – spielte Dorothea Ebert bei der Jubiläumsfeier das Bach-Werk, das sie während ihrer Inhaftierung unaufhörlich in Gedanken geübt hatte.
articles.prints:
Die Violinistin Dorothea Ebert setzte im Januar 1983 den Fluchtplan um, den sie schon seit langem vorbereitet hatte. Bei ihrem Fluchtversuch wurde sie an der bulgarischen Grenze verhaftet, nach Ostdeutschland zurückgeführt und zu einer Haftstrafe von zwei Jahren und acht Monaten verurteilt.
 Die Flucht, die in Dresden begonnen hatte, führte sie nach Ungarn, Rumänien und Bulgarien, aber letzten Endes schaffte sie es nicht über die westdeutsche Grenze.
 Trotz ihres überragenden musikalischen Talents musste sie unter strengster Überwachung als Musiklehrerin arbeiten. Letztendlich führte sie ihre Fluchtpläne aus, wurde aber entdeckt und ins Gefängnis gesperrt. Während Ebert, die davon träumte, ihr musikalisches Talent unbeschränkt zu entfalten, ihre Haftstrafe verbüßte, bezahlte Westdeutschland ihr Lösegeld, sodass sie endlich übersiedeln, ihren Traum verwirklichen und einen Schlussstrich unter die misslungene Flucht ziehen konnte.

articles.title: "New Music New Ground"
articles.title_sub: An escape story of an elite pianist from North Korea
articles.result: Since his emigration, Kim Cheol-woong has worked to organize a united youth orchestra for children from North Korean refugee camps and children from South Korea.
articles.prints: In October of 2001, senior pianist of the North Korean National Symphonic Orchestra, Kim Cheol-woong left his life as an elite musician behind and fled through China to South Korea. In North Korea, Mr. Kim was an established member of society, but in China he was only a lowly worker. His work was grueling and often put his hands in danger, but the thought of freely playing accompaniment piano in a church in South Korea drove him onward. While studying in Moscow earlier in his life, Kim was exposed to various musical genres and composers who were banned in North Korea. This forced him to begin to realize the limitations of his own country. Back at home, while practicing Richard Clayderman's "A Comme Amour" as part of a proposal plan to his girlfriend, he was discovered by the North Korean State Political Security Department. Jazz music was banned in North Korea and Mr. Kim was forced to write an apology explaining his actions. This incident motivated him to flee the country, as he could no longer endure the restrictions on the music he loved.

articles.title: „Ich konnte nicht nur die Musik spielen, die in meinem Land erlaubt war.“
articles.title_sub: Die Geschichte eines hochtalentierten Pianisten, der aus Nordkorea floh.
articles.result: Kim Cheol-Woong ist als Musikpädagoge tätig und äußerte seine Vision, junge nordkoreanische Flüchtlinge für ein innerkoreanisches Jugendorchester zu rekrutieren.
articles.prints:
Kim Chol-Ung, einer der besten Pianisten des Joson-Staatssymphonie-Orchesters, ließ im Oktober 2001 eine gesicherte Zukunft als Elite-Musiker hinter sich und setzte seinen Plan um, über China nach Südkorea zu fliehen.
In Nordkorea war er ein privilegierter Musiker, aber in China war er nur ein einfacher Arbeiter mit unsicherem Aufenthaltsstatus. Es gab zwar auch brenzlige Situationen, bei denen er seine Hände fast verletzt hätte, aber er arbeitete in einer Kirche als musikalischer Begleiter und wartete auf seine Chance, nach Südkorea überzusiedeln.
 Bei seinem Auslandsstudium in Moskau war er mit vielen musikalischen Genres in Kontakt gekommen, die er in Nordkorea nicht kennengelernt hatte, und machte auch die Bekanntschaft von neuen Musikerkollegen. Als ihm immer klarer wurde, welche Grenzen es für seinen musikalischen Handlungsspielraum in Nordkorea geben würde, passierte etwas, das sein Schicksal ändern würde.
 Als er Richard Claydermans „Herbstflüstern“ übte, um es seiner unerwiderten Liebe beim Heiratsantrag vorzuspielen, wurde er entdeckt. Jazzmusik zu spielen, war in Nordkorea verboten, und so wurde er wegen dieser Angelegenheit zum Sicherheitsministerium geführt und musste ein Entschuldigungsschreiben aufsetzen. Durch diesen Zwischenfall wurde ihm schmerzhaft bewusst, dass er nur die Musik spielen konnte, die in seinem Land erlaubt war, und beschloss, aus Nordkorea zu fliehen.

articles.title: "Fortune was a Ladder"
articles.title_sub: The window cleaner who avoided 18 shots at dawn
articles.result: At least 140 people were killed or died in connection to the Wall at the hands of the East German border regime between 1961 and 1989.
articles.prints: In the early morning of April 19th, 1988, a 31-year-old building cleaner attempted an escape near Berlin-Treptow in an effort to reach the West Berlin district of Neukölln. He surpassed the hinterland, or inner, wall but triggered the border signal zone alarm in the process. He quickly climbed over the 3.6 meter high west-facing Wall with the aid of his window cleaning ladder and successfully made it across the border. Miraculously, he managed to evade each of the border guards 18 total shots using only his ladder.

articles.title: „Das war die Leiter einer Glücksgöttin.“
articles.title_sub: Ein Gebäudereiniger entkommt im frühmorgendlichen Nebel 18 Pistolenschüssen.
articles.result: Die Zahl derer, die bei der Flucht aus Ostdeutschland an der Mauer erschossen wurden oder ihren Verletzungen erlagen, beläuft sich auf 140.
articles.prints:
Am frühen Morgen des 19. April 1988 floh ein 31-jähriger Gebäudereiniger von Treptow (Ostberlin) nach Neukölln (Westberlin) unter Zuhilfenahme einer Leiter.
 Obwohl zwei Wächter mit 18 Schüssen auf ihn zielten, wurde der Gebäudereiniger auf wundersame Weise nicht verletzt. Zwar wurde ein Alarm ausgelöst, aber das hielt den Gebäudereiniger nicht von seinem Vorhaben ab. Trotz der mehrstufigen Überwachungsvorrichtung wurde er nicht getroffen, und als er die letzte, 3,60 m hohe Mauer überstieg, nahm er eine Leiter, die er fürs Putzen genutzt hatte, so dass ihm die Flucht mühelos gelang.
 Die Grenzwächter sagten später aus, dass der Gebäudereiniger fliehen konnte, „weil er unglaublich schnell war und genau wusste, wohin die Schüsse zielen würden.“ Aber die Frage, warum sich in der Nähe der Mauer eine Leiter befand, konnte keiner beantworten.

articles.title: "A Search for Love in the Belly of A Dead Cow"
articles.title_sub: A girl's escape adventure in the 'Trojan Cow' in 1969
articles.result: The East German government realized it needed to increase security measures along the border strip, so in January 1970, they installed an automatic shooting system that would fire at detected movement. The system led to the deaths of a number of East German citizens and injured many more.
articles.prints: At 3:35 in the afternoon on November 13th, 2017, North Korean soldier, Oh Chung-sung defected to South Korea through the Panmunjom Joint Security Area (JSA). Mr. Oh stole a military jeep and rushed to the nearest army base at Panmunjom. He crashed into a ditch and was ejected from the vehicle, but somehow managed to reach the South Korean side. In the process, Mr. Oh sustained 5 gunshot wounds in the abdomen, pelvis, arms, and legs. After several surgeries, the North Korean soldier recovered enough to face a joint interrogation from the Unification Ministry and the National Intelligence Service of South Korea. Their questioning uncovered his motivation for escape to be malnutrition and hunger. In recognition of his recovery, Mr. Oh publicly expressed appreciation for the South Korean people and medical staff saying, “I hold it my duty to pay taxes and donate blood.”

articles.title: „Auf der Suche nach Liebe, im Bauch einer toten Kuh…“
articles.title_sub: Die abenteuerliche Geschichte einer jungen Frau, die sich 1969 in Ostdeutschland ereignet hat.
articles.result: Im Januar 1970 wurden im Grenzgebiet Selbstschussanlagen angebracht, also ein System, das jede Bewegung registriert und automatisch Schüsse abfeuert. Dadurch wurden Ostdeutsche, die über die Grenze fliehen wollten, automatisch verletzt oder getötet.
articles.prints:
Im Juli 1969 versuchte eine 18-jährige Frau aus Karl-Marx-Stadt (alte Bezeichnung, heute: Chemnitz) versteckt im Körper einer Kuh im ostdeutschen Drewitz über die Grenze zu flüchten.
 Die junge Frau versteckte sich im Körper einer Kuh, die ausgehöhlt worden war, damit Menschen hineinpassen. So wurde sie in einen LKW geladen und plante, mithilfe von zwei Komplizen über die Grenze fahren.
 Sie hatte zwar unter Einsatz ihres Lebens versucht, zu fliehen, um mit ihrem Verlobten in Westdeutschland zusammen zu sein, aber dann wurde sie entdeckt, ins Gefängnis gebracht und angeklagt. Sie wurde zu einer Haftstrafe verurteilt und während sie ihre Haft verbüßte, nach Westdeutschland freigekauft.

articles.title: "Runners Under the Wall"
articles.title_sub: The successful tunnel escape of two brothers in 1973
articles.result: Border fortifications continued in 1975 when the East German government introduced “Border Wall 75.” This update to the Wall included 3.6m by 1.2m L-shaped concrete walls lined side-by-side and were topped with a 40cm diameter pipe making it impossible to climb over or ram with a vehicle.
articles.prints: On July 7th, 1969, an 18-year-old girl from Karl Marx Stadt, now Chemnitz, attempted to escape East Germany in the hollowed out belly of a dead cow. With the help of two escape aids, the girl was supposed to be transported in the back of a small truck across the Drewitz border crossing in the East. The girl had hoped to join her fiance in West Germany, but was discovered and moved to a prison camp. All three involved were sentenced to prison, but the girl was eventually transferred to West Germany.

articles.title: „Wenn wir die Mauer nicht durchbohren können, werden wir eben darunter durchgehen.“
articles.title_sub: 1973, die Flucht zweier Brüder durch einen unterirdischen Tunnel.
articles.result:
Am nächsten Tag wurde der Tunnel, den die zwei Brüder gegraben hatten, mit Steinen, Sand und Beton geschlossen und verschwand somit an einemTag. Der Eingang zum Tunnel wurde mit einer 70 cm dicken Wand versperrt.


1975, zwei Jahre später, baute die ostdeutsche Regierung die „Grenzmauer 75“, um noch 
mehr Bürger an der Flucht zu hindern.
L-förmige Betonplatten von 3,60 m Höhe und 1,20 m Breite wurden nebeneinander 
eingesetzt. Dazu wurden röhrenförmige Betonelemente von 40 cm Durchmesser 
daraufgesetzt, sodass es nicht nur Menschen unmöglich war, die Mauer zu besteigen, sondern es auch für Fahrzeuge unmöglich war, die Mauer zu durchbrechen.
articles.prints:
In der Nacht vom 25. auf den 26. Juli 1973 flohen zwei Brüder mit ihren Ehefrauen und Kindern durch einen unterirdischen Tunnel von Klein-Glieniecke in Ostberlin nach Zehlendorf in Westberlin.
 Die Brüder gruben sich mit einer Kinderschaufel und einem stiellosen Spaten durch den Untergrund, schütteten die Erde in ihrem Keller auf und gruben so einen insgesamt 19 m langen Tunnel. Dieser Tunnel führte zu einem Keller, der sich unterhalb der Mauer befand, und der Ausgang war nur 80 cm von der Westberliner Seite der Mauer entfernt. Um nicht entdeckt zu werden, versteckten sich die zwei Brüder mit ihren Familien im Untergrund und passten einen günstigen Moment ab. Doch unter den Verwandten der Brüder befand sich eine Denunziantin.
 Als die Ostberliner Geheimpolizei, die von dem Fluchtplan erfahren hatte, ankam, waren die zwei Brüder und ihre Familien schon in einem Westberliner Notaufnahmelager, so dass die Polizei kehrtmachen musste. Direkt am nächsten Tag wurde der Tunnel mit Steinen, Sand und Beton zugeschüttet und innerhalb von einem Tag unpassierbar gemacht. Der Eingang zum Tunnel wurde mit einer 70 cm dicken Mauer versperrt.

articles.title: "I Hold it my Duty to Pay Taxes and Donate Blood"
articles.title_sub: The North Korean defector who escaped 40 gunshots
articles.result: After Mr. Oh Chung-sung defected, North Korea replaced all military personnel near Panmunjom and never requested repatriation.
articles.prints: During the nights of July 25th and 26th, 1973, two brothers, who lived in the Klein Glienicke neighborhood of East Berlin, attempted to flee to West Berlin with their wives and five children through a 19 meter self-built tunnel in the cellar of a building material warehouse. Using only a children’s shovel and handless spade, the brothers transferred the dirt with a wood chipper up into the cellar. Their target was only 80 centimeters past the border on the West Berlin side, so their margin for error was very slim. Unfortunately, a close relative of the family informed the East German secret police, the Stasi, of the family’s intention to flee. The Stasi intervened immediately, but the families had already made it safely to the Marienfelde refugee center in West Berlin.

articles.title: „Ich werde zuverlässig meine Steuern zahlen und auch viel Blut spenden.“
articles.title_sub: Ein nordkoreanischer Soldat, der unter 40 Schüssen am Panmunjom in den Süden überläuft.
articles.result: Nachdem Oh Cheong-Seong in den Süden übergelaufen war, wurden alle Soldaten, die auf der nördlichen Seite des Panmunjom stationiert waren, ausgewechselt, und es gab auch keine ausdrückliche Forderung nach Rückführung.
articles.prints:
Oh Cheong-Seong, der als Fahrer für das nordkoreanische Militär arbeitete, fuhr am 13. November 2017 gegen 15 Uhr 35 durch die Joint Security Area in Panmunjom. 
 Dabei wurde er von den Schüssen der ihn verfolgenden nordkoreanischen Soldaten getroffen.
 Er raste mit einem Armee-Jeep am Wachposten der nordkoreanischen Armee vorbei, der am nächsten an der Demarkationslinie war. Dabei fiel sein Wagen in einen Graben. Er stieg sofort aus und rannte auf den nächsten südkoreanischen Wachposten zu. Dabei wurde er von nordkoreanischen Soldaten am Bauch und am Becken sowie an beiden Armen und Beinen getroffen und hatte Schusswunden an über fünf Stellen.
 Oh wurde mehrmals operiert und erholte sich gesundheitlich. Derweil gab der Nachrichtendienst, der seine Informationen unter anderem aus dem Verteidigungsministerium und dem nationalen Geheimdienst bezog, in den Zeitungen bekannt, dass er aus einem starken Impuls heraus übergelaufen sei, und weil er den Hunger nicht mehr ertragen habe.
 Als Herr Oh erfuhr, dass es für seine Operationen nötig gewesen war, auf die Blutspenden von Südkoreanern zurückzugreifen, und dass er dank ihrer Blutspenden überlebt hatte, sagte er dem Krankenhauspersonal, dass er „zuverlässig seine Steuern zahlen und viel Blut spenden werde.“

articles.title: “The Wall Must be Remembered”
articles.title_sub: Manfred Fischer, “Wall pastor” and creator of the Berlin Wall Memorial
articles.result: Manfred Fischer was the pastor of the Reconciliation Church, which was demolished as a result of the expanding border strip. After reunification, he worked as the chairman of the Berlin Wall Foundation and devoted his efforts to honoring the victims who lost their lives at the Wall.
articles.prints: After the collapse of the Berlin Wall in 1989, the pastor of the Reconciliation Church, Manfred Fischer built and dedicated the Berlin Wall Memorial on Bernauer Street to the victims who lost their lives at the Wall. Fischer eventually convinced the neighboring citizens to permanently preserve this section Wall, to and establish a memorial foundation, and to rebuild the Reconciliation Church. He emphasized, "Do not forget the way to heal the wounds of history," in a plea to preserve original parts of the Wall in an effort to remind the people of the history and the lives lost.

articles.title: „Man muss die Erinnerung an die Mauer wachhalten.“
articles.title_sub: Der ‚Mauerpfarrer Manfred Fischer‘, der Mitbegründer der Mauer-Gedenkstätte in Berlin.
articles.result:
Manfred Fischer war der Pfarrer der Versöhnungskirche, die im Zuge der Mauer-Ausweitung gesprengt wurde.
Nach der Wiedervereinigung fungierte er als Vorsitzender des Vereins Berliner Mauer und 
scheute keine Mühen, der Opfer zu gedenken. Er starb 2013.
articles.prints:
Nachdem die Berliner Mauer 1989 gefallen war, errichtete Pfarrer Manfred Fischer eine Gedenkstätte in der Bernauer Straße, durch die die Mauer verlaufen war. Dort ließ er im Andenken an die Menschen, die an der Mauer ihr Leben verloren hatten, auch einen Park anlegen.
 Er startete eine erfolgreiche Bürgerinitiative für den Bau einer Mauergedenkstätte, um die Erinnerung fortwährend lebendig zu halten, und war auch beim Wiederaufbau der Versöhnungskirche ganz vorne dabei.
 Sein Credo war: „Man heilt die Wunden der Geschichte, indem man sie nicht vergisst.“ So ließ er relevante Reste der Berliner Mauer erhalten und betonte, dass man die Geschichte der Mauer und das Gedenken an die Opfer auch für die nachfolgenden Generationen lebendig halten muss.

articles.title: "I Will Draw a Painting That Conveys Freedom"
articles.title_sub: Painter, Song Byeok flees twice through the Tumen River
articles.result: The artist Song Byeok said, "I will draw a picture telling the reality of North Korea and conveying freedom to the people of North Korea" who suffer only because they were born there.
articles.prints: Born in 1969 in the Hwanghae Province, Mr. Song Byeok swam across the Tumen River to escape North Korea in 2000 and in 2001. Before defecting, Mr. Song worked as a propaganda painter in North Korea. He depicted scenes demanded by the regime and never questioned it. Now living in South Korea, Song makes pop art pictures that criticize the North Korean government and people. Mr. Song remembers his time painting happy pictures in North Korea as one of total sadness. Defecting from North Korea was never his plan, but after the famine of the late 1990s he and his father crossed the Tumen River in 2000 to search for food. His father got swept away and drowned during the escape attempt and Song was captured. He was forced into a labor camp after being interrogated and beaten. His time in prison confirmed his new understanding of the North Korean regime, and he became committed to escaping again across the Tumen River, even if it meant death. He was successful in his second attempt in 2001 and now is an established painter with solo shows in South Korea and the United States. His ultimate dream is to hold a solo exhibition in North Korea dedicated to freedom.

articles.title: „Ich werde Bilder über die Freiheit malen.“
articles.title_sub: Der Maler Song Byeok, der bei seiner Flucht aus Nordkorea zwei Mal durch den Tumen-Fluss geschwommen ist.
articles.result: Song Byeok gab bekannt, dass er gerade deshalb, weil er in Nordkorea geboren wurde, für sein leidendes Volk Bilder malen wolle, die die Realität Nordkoreas zeigen, und zugleich die Freiheit propagieren.
articles.prints:
Song Byeok, der 1969 in der nordkoreanischen Provinz Hwanghae-do geboren wurde, floh zwei Mal, in den Jahren 2000 und 2002 mit nichts als den Kleidern, die er am Leib trug, durch den Fluss Tumen nach China.
 Vor seiner Flucht aus Nordkorea hatte Song Byeok für die Regierung gearbeitet. Seine Tätigkeit bestand darin, Bilder, Plakate, Fotos und Slogans zu produzieren und anzubringen. Er malte nur Motive, die das Regime in Auftrag gab, und für ihn war das eine ganz selbstverständliche Aufgabe. Allerdings sahen diese Bilder ganz anders aus als die Bilder, die er später in Südkorea gemalt hat. Jetzt malt er hauptsächlich Bilder im Pop Art-Stil, in denen er die das Regime kritisiert und ungeschönt das hässliche Gesicht Nordkoreas zeigt. Über seine Vergangenheit als Künstler in Nordkorea sagt er: „Ich malte Bilder vom Glück, obwohl ich gar nicht glücklich war.“
 Song Byeok hatte nicht von Anfang an vor, zu fliehen. Im Jahre 2000 war er mit seinem Vater geflohen, um Nahrungsmittel zu suchen. Während sie den Fluss durchquerten, verlor er seinen Vater, suchte Grenzwachen auf und bat sie, seinen Vater zu retten, aber stattdessen wurde er gefoltert und verhört. Später wurde er verurteilt und in ein Straflager gesteckt, wo er unter den härtesten Bedingungen arbeiten musste.
 Während seiner Inhaftierung erkannte er, wie die Verhältnisse in Nordkorea wirklich waren und beschloss zu fliehen, auch wenn das den Tod bedeuten würde, und so durchquerte er den Tumen ein zweites Mal. Jetzt hat er Einzelausstellungen in Südkorea und den USA und hat sich damit als Künstler etabliert. Sein größter Traum ist „eine Einzelausstellung in Nordkorea, mit Bildern, die die Freiheit propagieren“.

articles.title: "An East and West Berlin Joint Operation"
articles.title_sub: The story of a successful escape through a cable reel in the dead of night
articles.result: The border crossing at Helmstedt-Marienborn was the largest in Berlin, supporting 70% of all passenger and cargo traffic during the German division. The checkpoint was closed after reunification but there remains a memorial.
articles.prints: With the help of West German escape aids, six East Berliners succeeded in fleeing to the West tucked away in a West Berlin power plant (BEWAG) wooden cable reel. The team set their escape for a cold winter night in January 1965 to avoid the heavy surveillance of the Marienborn-Helmstedt border crossing. The West Berlin escape helpers cut an unobtrusive opening in the reel, loaded it onto a truck, and transported it  over the border using the standard transit route. The helpers came up with the idea when they realized they could move multiple East Germans at one time in the 2 meter high cable reel, which was easily disguisable when crossing the border.

articles.title: „Große gemeinsame Fluchtaktion von ost- und westdeutschen Bürgern.“
articles.title_sub: In einer Nacht haben Flüchtlinge sich in Kabelrollen versteckt und konnten unentdeckt den Grenzübergang passieren.
articles.result:
Während der deutschen Teilung wurden 70% des Reise- und Güterverkehrs am Grenzübergang Marienborn/ Helmstedt abgewickelt. Damit war dies der meistfrequentierte Grenzübergang.
Nach der Wiedervereinigung wurde der Betrieb am Grenzübergang eingestellt. Jetzt wird er als „Gedenkstätte Deutsche Teilung Marienborn“ genutzt.
articles.prints:
Im Januar 1965 gelang es sechs Ostdeutschen mit der Unterstützung von zwei westdeutschen Helfern in einer Nacht, als die Grenzwachen unaufmerksam waren, versteckt in hölzernen Kabelrollen der Berliner Elektrizitätswerke über die Grenze bei Marienborn/ Helmstedt in den Westen zu fliehen.
 Die Fluchthelfer hatten einen unauffälligen Einstieg in die Kabelrolle gesägt, durch den man hineinklettern konnte. Anschließend luden sie die Kabelrollen in ihren LKW und fuhren die Transitstrecke entlang.
 Die ostdeutschen Flüchtlinge sollten den Grenzübergang passieren und bis nach Hannover kommen, wo die westdeutschen Helfer auf sie warteten. Dort wurden sie in den über 2 m hohen Kabelrollen versteckt und erfolgreich in den Westen gebracht.

article_link.desc: Erich Honecker of East Germany crossed the Wall to the West and Kim Jong Un of North Korea crossed the MDL(military demarcation line) to the South, each for the first time.

Erich Honecker, der die Mauer hinter sich ließ, um Westdeutschland zu besuchen,
und Kim Jong-un, der die Demarkationslinie überschritt, um Südkorea zu besuchen
The first summit after the division; Willy Brandt of West Germany visited the East and Kim Dae-jung of South Korea visited the North.
Das erste Gipfeltreffen zwischen Ost- und Westdeutschland beziehungsweise zwischen Nord- und Südkorea seit der Teilung
Both countries, West Germany in 1971 and South Korea in 2000, had Nobel Peace Prize winners who tried to overcome the conflicts between two divided countries.
Überwindung der Teilung durch Gespräch und Zusammenarbeit. Brandt und Kim Dae-Jung erhalten den Friedensnobelpreis für ihre Bemühungen.
The Basic Treaty of East and West Germany and the Basic Inter-Korean Agreement are the first agreements between the divided countries and ultimately set the foundations for unification.
Der erste umfassende Vertrag, in dem Ost- und Westdeutschland und Nord- und Südkorea ihre Beziehung definieren, legt die grundlegenden Parameter für die Vereinigung der beiden Länder fest.
The ideological conflicts extended beyond the divided nations.
Eine Phase, die wegen ideologischer Differenzen auch bei den diplomatischen Beziehungen äußerste Vorsicht erfordert
West Germany and South Korea provided economic aid to East Germany and North Korea respectively.
Ostdeutschland und Nordkorea öffnen ihre Herzen aufgrund von wirtschaftlichen Beihilfen
The Berlin Wall and the Korean DMZ; concrete walls and barbed wires on the borders that divided people.
Betonmauer und Stacheldrahtzaun trennen sowohl die Bürger zwischen Ost- und Westdeutschland als auch zwischen Nord- und Südkorea
Surveillance existed on both the Berlin Wall and the Korean DMZ.
Überwachung und Kontrolle entlang der Grenze

Both entailed underground conflicts between two divided nations
*Tunnel 57 was made for escape, while the 3rd tunnel was made for invasion.

Angespannte Lage zwischen den geteilten Ländern, die den Boden unter ihnen spaltet
(Aber der Unterschied ist, dass Tunnel 57 für die Flucht, der dritte unterirdische Runnel jedoch für die Invasion gedacht ist)
Reconciliation and understanding each other through cultural exchanges.
Förderung des gegenseitigen Verständnisses durch Kunst und Kulturaustausch und Beitrag zur Wiederherstellung der Homogenität beider Völker
Cultural impact on the people regardless of ideology.
Die Menschen kommen sich durch Kultur unabhängig von Politik und Ideologie näher
Music makes harmony of divided people.
Die Völker werden durch die Musik vereint
The conflicts and attitudes of division permeate into sporting life.
Eine Phase, in der man sich auch im ideologiefreien Sport gegenüber steht
Sports events that showed the possibility for the unification
Eine Sportveranstaltung, bei der die Teilung überwunden wird und die Versöhnung im Vordergrund steht
Two divided nations came together for the Olympics.
Erste gemeinsame Teilnahme an den Olympischen Spielen seit der Teilung
Musicians who fled to avoid state control
Musiker entziehen sich der Kontrolle ihres Landes und brechen auf, um Freiheit zu finden
People who experienced the tragic division of the countries and evaded death during their escapes.
Menschen, die die schmerzhafte Geschichte der Teilung selbst erlebt haben

clues.desc: Erich Honecker, the General Secretary of East Germany
from September 7 to September 11, 1987, for total of 5 days
visited West Germany and held a summit with Helmut Kohl.
The East and West German summit promised cooperation in the fields of science and technology in an effort to ease the inconvenience that travelers faced when visiting their neighboring nation.
West Germany held a magnificent welcome ceremony in honor of the visiting East German prime minister, and Honecker became the first East German head of state to visit West Germany.
As an outcome of the summit, East Germany was acknowledged as an independent state and the two countries entered a new phase of diplomatic relations.
South Korean President Moon Jae-in and Kim Jong-un of North Korea
on April 27, 2018
at the South Korean side of Panmunjom in the Korean DMZ
held the Inter-Korean summit and announced the Panmunjom Declaration for Peace, Prosperity, and Unification of the Korean Peninsula.

The summit was resumed 11 years after the former South Korean President, Roh Moo-hyun, and North Korean leader, Kim Jong-il, held talks in Pyongyang on October 4, in 2007. The historical meeting of the two leaders was broadcast live throughout the Korean peninsula as well as all over the world. The participants went on walks together, exchanged stories about the military demarcation line (MDL), took photographs, and held special ceremonies. The appearance of the two leaders crossing the military demarcation line together  into the North and then back down to the South made a strong impression on all those watching the talks.

Through the Panmunjom Declaration, which came as a result of the summit, the 65-year-old armistice agreement was transformed into a peace treaty and the Inter-Korean cooperation and exchange programs were resumed.
Chancellor Willy Brandt of West Germany and Prime Minister Willi Stoph of East Germany
on March 19th, 1970, after 25 years of continued division
in Erfurt, a major city of East Germany near the border
held the first summit between East and West Germany.

East Germans welcomed West German chancellor Brandt as he arrived by train and even cheered his name at his nearby hotel. While East and West Germany failed to narrow the political gap during their talks, they agreed that "war should not begin in Germany again."

The first summit meeting in Erfurt showed that the West German government accepted the reality of two existing German states and was willing to setup official diplomatic relations, allowing for further summits to follow.
Willy Brandt of West Germany
from October 1969 to May 1974, carried out the eastern policy (Ostpolitik) that became the political cornerstone for German reunification.
In his inaugural address as West German chancellor in 1969,
he announced the eastern policy of “acknowledging the existence of East Germany and promoting normal diplomacy with the communist countries.”
West Germany then regained normal diplomatic relations with countries whose reputations had been weakened by the Hallstein Doctrine. This ultimately led to reconciliation with the East.
Brandt decided to recognize the reality of the division in an effort to take "the small steps" to build trust and bolster relations between the East and West in daily life.
South Korean President Kim Dae-jung
carried out the policy of reconciliation and cooperation towards North Korea, deeming it the Sunshine or Engagement Policy, during his administration.
The entire Korean peninsula was transformed from a place of military confrontation to one of exchange and cooperation.

Grounded in peace, reconciliation, and cooperation, the Sunshine Policy was based on the principles that all armed provocations are prohibited, that absorption unification shall not be attempted, and that these goals must be actively pursued.
As a result of the inter-Korean summit of 2000, economic exchange between the nations increased, cooperation for humanitarian aid to North Korea was promoted, and separated families were reunited.
It was an effort to maintain the fundamental principle of "peace first, then unification", to ease military confrontation between the two Koreas, and to increase informal exchanges.
South Korean President Kim Dae-jung and Supreme Leader of North Korea Kim Jong-il
held the first Inter-Korean summit that lasted two nights and three days from June 13th to June 15th, 2000
in Pyongyang, the capital of North Korea.
In the final hours of the talks, the <6.15 South-North Joint Declaration> was announced.
President Kim Dae-jung and Chairman Kim Jung-il wrote at 11 pm,
“In the hope of peaceful unification and system coexistence on the Korean peninsula, we will expand inter-Korean economic cooperation and exchanges in various fields.”
Junior Minister of East Germany, Michael Kohl and West German Minister, Egon Bahr
on December 21st, 1972
signed the Basic Treaty in East Berlin.
The treaty contained a total of 10 provisions, including that the two nations "develop friendly relations on the basis of equal rights.”
A new, more willing East German regime, in conjunction with thawing international tempers, made the signing of the Basic Treaty possible.

The signing of the treaty paved the way for the two German states to be recognized by the international community. And it opened the door to official relationships between East and West Germany, allowing for many more agreements on economic relations, cultural exchanges, and traffic and travel affairs to take place.
The prime ministers of North and South Korea
on December 13th, 1991,
at the fifth ministerial talks in Seoul
signed an Inter-Korean Basic Agreement.

The North and South have held five high-level inter-Korean talks since 1990 and have sought consensus on reconciliation and exchanges. The agreement included principles and procedures for reconciliation and cooperation, mutual non-aggression and exchange, and an understanding that after 46 years of division, the two sides agreed to resolve all issues through dialogue and negotiation.

The Inter-Korean Basic Agreement can be seen in conjunction with the disintegration of the socialist camps that began in the 1980s and the global post-Cold War era. As a result, a foundation for peaceful unification was laid, a forum for dialogue was opened, and the timeclock for unification began to tick.
As the General Secretary of the Socialist Unity Party of East Germany, Erich Honecker authorized intercity exchange programs
starting in 1986 with Eisenhüttenstadt in East Germany and Saarlouis in West Germany.
East and West Germany had 62 partnerships and more than 500 applications until the programs ended in 1989.
Various town-twinning programs included the exchange of municipal experts, athletes, and youth activities.
Despite the wishes to have inter-city exchanges immediately after the country’s division, negotiations did not begin until 1985 and were strongly controlled by the East German government.
The twinned city model in East and West Germany proved to narrow the cultural, emotional, political, and administrative gaps upon reunification.
Walter Hallstein, the leading civil servant at the West German Foreign Office,
in the Cold War era of the 1950s,
played a major role in West German foreign policy, giving his name to the Hallstein Doctrine.

His ideology influenced West German foreign policy and carried consequences for many nearby nations. It meant that the West German government would regard it as an "unfriendly act" if any third-party countries were to recognize or maintain official diplomatic relations with East Germany.
The doctrine was applied to Yugoslavia in 1957, who had recognized East Germany, with the exception of the Soviet Union, as one of the Four Powers responsible for the German territory.

This policy was backed by the idea that West Germany was the only successor to the German Reich and the only legitimate state in Germany to establish a government through free elections, and it was intended to prevent East Germany from claiming a voice in the international community as an independent country.
The South Korean government
in February 1989, when it first established diplomatic relations with Hungary,
did not have diplomatic ties with any communist countries, including China.
Since the entry into the Korean war, China has been classified as an enemy country, and has adhered to their principle of not dealing with the United States or any pro-American states.
Accordingly, South Korea could only trade indirectly through third-party countries, and China exerted its influence over the Korean peninsula through its interaction with North Korea.

The close relationship between China and North Korea has made it impossible for South Korea to establish diplomatic ties with China and other communist nations. However, with time, the ties between South Korea and other communist nations were improved as self interest began to thaw hostile political relationships.
Regardless of its changing political inclinations, The West German government,
before unification from 1971 until 1989
aided the construction of regional infrastructure in East Germany
with an investment of 11.4 billion marks.

Four freeways were built to open up West Berlin. The construction of the new Berlin-Hamburg highway, which began in 1978, underwent a change of regime management but was continued to be invested in and was eventually completed in 1982.
Road construction continued along with trade, travel, and other regular exchanges as East-West relations converged.
The East German government had revenue streams of foreign currency
since 1968, until a public transit agreement was finally reached.
The GDR introduced passport and visa obligations at border crossing points for residents of West Germany who wanted to visit West Berlin.

A passport had to be submitted when crossing the border. In addition, a transit visa had to be requested from the East German authorities for each trip that traveled through East Germany to get to West Berlin. These visas were issued at border crossing points as an attachment to a valid West Berlin identity card or to a Federal German passport.

For this, the East German government was able to charge a fee. A one-time transit visa cost 5 DM, a two-time transit visa cost 10 DM, and a visa for entry (if people did not just want to travel through) cost 15 DM.
The fees collected for almost 8 million travelers from West Germany were a significant source of foreign currency for the East German government.
Erich Honecker, the Socialist Unity Party leader and head of government of the German Democratic Republic
in October 1979
during the 30th anniversary of the establishment of the East German regime
provocatively kissed Leonid Brezhnev, the secretary of the Communist Party of the Soviet Union,
immediately upon Brezhnev’s arrival at the ceremony to a room full of cameras and reporters who were broadcasting the event to the world.
East Germany and the Soviet Union were essential to one another as they served as the two axes of the European communist regime.
The Korean Electric Power Corporation of South Korea,
in March 2005, supplied electricity to North Korean local enterprises 57 years after the North cut off power to the South in 1948,
in the Gaesong Industrial Pilot Complex, where the companies had to use their own generators before.

This was the first delivery of electricity to North Korea since the division. The Kumgang Mountain and the Kaesong Industrial Complex projects are milestones that mark the first time that electricity from the South will enter the North in 57 years.
Once the necessary work and safety checks are complete, officials say the supply of electricity will be ready for use by tenant companies.

The North’s expanding military facilities and transmission line problems were reasons the transfer of electricity to the affiliated companies was a long and difficult process. With the pilot complex as a first step, economic cooperation between the two Koreas is expected to become more active.
North Korean President Kim Jong-un and US President Donald Trump
on June 12, 2018, 65 years after the Armistice Agreement was signed in 1953
held the first historic US-North Korean summit in Singapore.

At the talks, the two leaders agreed on a number of items, three of which included the complete denuclearization of North Korea, a normalization of relations with North Korea, and repatriation of victims of the Korean war.
After 65 years of confrontation and stand off, and after many insults and insinuations of withdrawal from President Trump, the two nations were finally able to reduce the tension through the summit.

2017 marked a dramatic increase in North Korea’s nuclear missile test launches, which exacerbated their conflict with the US. However, an inter-Korean summit was held on April 27th after the 2018 Pyeongchang Winter Olympics, accelerating and allowing for the US-North Korean summit to take place.
Chung Ju-young, Honorary President of the Hyundai Group
travelled twice on June 16th and October 27th, 1998,
through the MDL(Military Demarcation Line) at Panmunjom
and donated 500 cows on the first visit and 501 cows on the second to North Korea.
Honorary President, Chung loaded ten cows to one truck and passed the military demarcation line. The 1,001 total cows were raised at the Seosan Ranch in South Korea and most were pregnant.

Mr. Chung passed through Panmunjom as a private citizen before and knew it to be the appropriate location to present his gift of donated cows to North Korea. After much thought and deliberation, North Korea accepted honorary president Chung’s proposal in an effort to address the national food shortage and promote the development of Kumgang Mountain.
Supreme Leader Kim Jong-il of North Korea
in the 1996 New Year's co-editorial, announced and emphasized the spirit of the “Arduous March.”
Floods, food shortages, and a deteriorating economy were occurring in North Korea.

The Arduous March stemmed from the experience of former leader Kim Il-sung who suffered from 100 days of marching in the cold to avoid Japanese subjugation in Manchuria from the end of 1938 to early 1939.

While soldiers and construction workers set out to build new power stations and railroads, the march of hardship was present throughout all aspects of society including science, literature, and physical education. Especially in the fields of art and culture, movies, songs, and lyrical poetry were produced in the spirit of the march.

The Arduous March was framed as a wayto overcome economic hardship, social deviation, and hunger, which persisted through the 1990s, but ultimately to represent the sacrifice of the people and loyalty to their ruler. However, the Arduous March served really as a political slogan that aimed to remind the people of North Korea of the major issues plaguing the nation, like rampant disease.
As the number of East Germans fleeing into West German, the East German government,
on August 13th, 1961, mobilized soldiers and blocked the border
between East and West Berlin.

East Germany blocked all traffic in and out of West Berlin and set up a wall on the border of the entire city. As a result, West Berlin became an “island in the land” completely surrounded by East German soil.
The construction of the Berlin Wall began with barbed wire, fences, and bricks stacked up to block roads and windows.

When the number of East German migrants exceeded 3 million and the economic status of the nation worsened, the East German government attempted to contain the issue and their people by building the Wall. The Berlin Wall evolved as fortresses equipped with weapons and stationed with soldiers on shoot-to-kill orders.
The representatives of the United Nations, North Korea and China
on July 27, 1953, when the Korean War was still in full swing, signed the Korean War Armistice Agreement.
The agreement required that there be a line that went from the Imjin River to the East Sea,
so the representatives agreed to organize 1,292 piles of shrubbery into a makeshift Military Demarcation Line (MDL).
The Korean Demilitarized Zone (DMZ) was created based on the MDL, with a 2 kilometer “no man’s land” to the north and south.

It was agreed to withdraw all remaining military forces from the combat areas to prevent further armed conflicts. Established Guard Posts (GPs) in the North and South have always had armed guards, but since 1963 North Korea has also built fortifications, organized sieges, and reinforced barbed-wire fences.
The East German government,
from 1952 to 1989, as East Berliners kept escaping to the West
between the inner and outer walls of the border strip at the Berlin Wall,
installed a total of 280 watchtowers.
The surveillance watchtowers were continuously updated to prevent East Germans from escaping.
Not even the 280 watchtowers could suppress the people’s will for freedom. Nearly 4,900 made the treacherous journey West over the Berlin Wall before it collapsed.
Students from West Berlin
on the nights of October 3rd and 4th, 1964,
through a tunnel they dug that connected an old bakery on the West side to the back of an East side apartment building on Strelitzer Strasse near the Berlin Wall,
aided the escape of 57 East Berliners, marking the most successful escape attempt ever recorded. Most of the tunnels were detected or abandoned before they were finished.
Using shovels to dig and buckets to remove dirt, the students dug the 11m deep tunnel over a period of 5 months.
Many of the tunnel diggers were young East Germans who had fled successfully and felt the need to “do something” to reunite with their loved ones and others separated by the Wall.
The South Korean Army, who received intelligence information from their surveyor of North Korean tunnels,
on October 17, 1978, carried out a reverse excavation operation
just 52 km away from Seoul in Jangdan-myeon, Gyeonggi-do,

discovered the Third Tunnel of Aggression. The tunnel was 1.95m in width, 2.1m in height, and 1.6km in length, allowing 30,000 North Korean Troops, lined four at a time side-by-side, and weapons to move across the border in a single hour.

For years, the South Korean Army had worked with US forces to discover and strike tunnels nestled along the DMZ, but little progress was made until finally a South Korean soldier reported hearing an explosion that ultimately gave away the location of the Third Infiltration Tunnel.
The Third Tunnel was revealed to the world when Kim Bu-sung, who worked as a mining surveyor in North Korea, reporting seeing North Korean Troops digging a tunnel “towards the cottonwood tree.”
The Ministry of National Defense of South Korea
since 2015
at the monitoring stations (Guard Posts, GP) in the Korean Demilitarized Zone (DMZ)
advanced monitoring facilities including thermal imaging closure
organizing the budget of 17.5 billion won for the installation.
The surveillance system was strengthened as the North Korean military increasingly threatened the boundaries of the Military Demarcation Line (MDL).
The West German government,
from 1963 until the collapse of the Berlin Wall in 1989,
for the release of captured East German escapees and political prisoners in camps
paid East Germany, in cash or goods, through an in formal program called "Freikauf."
The project was initiated by private organizations such as churches and lawyers because the East and West governments weren’t willing to formally address the issue.

“Freikauf” was a secret agreement initiated when the number of captured East German escapees increased dramatically. It is estimated that a total of 33,755 people were repatriated at a cost of 3,464 million marks.
Resistance demonstrators in East Germany,
on September 4th, 1989, after the regular Monday worship at the Nikolai Church
in Leipzig, carried out a peaceful demonstration.
The demonstrators cried for freedom and held banners in support of free travel, speech, and expression.

The protests were reported on in West Germany, resulting in a ban on West German reporters from visiting East Germany. However, every Monday after worship, the scale of the demonstrations increased as did the number citizens attending the Nikolai Church. The East German Secret Police did their best to suppress the protests through military mobilization, but their efforts proved futile against the hundreds of thousands of people gathered.

The East German government tried to negotiate with the people after they failed to suppress the demonstrations, but ultimately Prime Minister Erich Honecker resigned and the East German Travel Relations Act was amended to allow free travel. The core requirements of the protesters were peacefully met.
Günter Schabowski, the official speaker of the SED (Socialist Unity Party of Germany) of East Germany,

on November 9, 1989, at a press conference regarding the enactment of the Travel Relations Act 
announced that East German residents could travel to West Germany on a free trip. 
When asked by an Italian reporter when the legislation would take effect, Schabowski, who was never given an official start date, apprehensively replied, "immediately."
East German residents watching the press conference rushed to the Berlin Wall immediately.
Crowds of people began to gather around the Wall’s crosspoints and cry out for the guards to open the gates.
Around midnight, checkpoint officers opened all the border crossings to allow East Germans to cross into West Germany. Some people even began smashing the Berlin Wall with axes and hammers.
Schabowski’s minor slip of the tongue proved to be the catalyst of the collapse of the Berlin Wall, but its downfall was really only possible given the inexorable efforts of the East German citizens.
The East and West German governments,
in May 1986, thirteen years after the signing of the Basic Treaty,
decided to greatly expand cultural and artistic exchanges between East and West Germany
by signing what’s known as the Cultural Agreement.
Some of the cultural exchanges included soap operas, concerts, artistic exhibitions, student and scholar swaps, an exchange of books and information on cultural heritage, and even data lending.

After the signing of the Basic Treaty, initial discussions for such cultural exchanges began as early as November 1973, but agreements were hard to reach as the two nations’ political preferences differed immensely. East Germany constantly criticized the West for its socialist tendencies and cultural infiltration. Ultimately, the Cultural Agreement, alongside broadcast media like TV and radio, narrowed the gap between the values and mindsets of the East and West residents.
The South and North Korean art troupes
for a total of four days from September 20th to 23rd, 1985,
visited Panmunjom, Seoul and Pyongyang respectively.
In an effort to minimize any political commentary, the content of the art performance was composed mainly of traditional ethnic folk music.
The South Korean art troupe performed at the Pyongyang Grand Theater and the North Korean art troupe performed at the Seoul National Theater.

The performances of the inter-Korean troupes were conducted in conjunction with the reunion of separated families on South Korea's 61st anniversary of Liberation Day. It was the first time in the history of the two nations’ division that a family reunion event was accompanied by art performances, which was seen by many Koreans as culturally touching.
East German residents,
from the 1970s onward
and in the privacy of their homes, were able to illegally watch West German public broadcasting.

In 1978, the West German public broadcasting news program “Heute” had a 40% audience rating in East Germany, which was higher than that of West Germany at the time. By 1985, 85% of the residents of East Germany regularly reported on West German public broadcasting news.

At the beginning of the division, the East German government banned people from watching West German broadcasts and even collected antennas, but it turned out to be impossible to completely block them given the similarities in the transmission systems of the East and West broadcasts. As the East and West German exchanges began to take off in the 1970s, West German broadcasting was tacitly accepted.

West German public broadcasting tried to provide objective news through local coverage by excluding slanderous stories in an effort to help the East German people grasp their realities accurately. This contributed to a narrowing of the psychological distance between the residents of East and West Germany after German reunification.
The worldwide pop star, David Bowie
in June 1987
performed three days at the outdoor plaza in front of the Reichstag building in West Berlin.
It was so close to the Berlin Wall that residents in East Berlin could hear his voice.
The East German residents followed along to every song and David Bowie even turned the speakers back towards East Berlin for those who were singing across the Wall.

On the day of the final show, David Bowie chose to sing “Heroes” as his last song. The song depicts a pair of lovers who met in front of the Berlin Wall, and was made while Bowie was recording in West Berlin at the famous Hansa Studio, known as the “studio at the Wall.” Police tried to control the mass audience around the Wall, but only exasperated the crowd into protest.
A group of South Korean pop musicians led by Yun-sang
from March 31 to April 4, 2018
at the East Pyongyang Theater and the Chung Ju-Yeong Stadium in Pyongyang
successfully performed their “Spring Comes" concert and held the North-South joint performance “We Are The One.”

After much hard work and consideration of prior agreements, South Korean director Yun-sang and North Korean director Hyeon Song-wol reached an agreement and ultimately received high praise for their performances from audiences in Pyongyang and at the Pyeongchang Olympics of 2018. Their collaboration opened the door to future inter-Korean art, cultural, and sporting exchanges.

Do Jong-Hwan, the Minister of Culture, Sports and Tourism of South Korea, has delivered Kim Jong-Un's message that he looks forward to the next performance in autumn, which indicates a prosperous future of exchanges between North and South Korea.
The young generation of North Koreans,
since the 1990s, has thrived on a black market called “jangmadang.”
Jangmadang is the North Korean people's secret market that was born after the worst famine, or the so-called “Arduous March” of the late 1990s.
Among the items sold there are DVDs and USBs that contain South Korean movies and soap operas.

Officially, North Korean people are banned from watching South Korean videos but according to the testimonies of foreign reporters and some North Korean refugees people often find ways to secretly watch together with friends.

The tone and style of the main characters in the soap operas or moviee naturally permeates and is popular among the North Korean people, and there are a few cases that some refugees from the North Korea said South Korean movies provoked their escapes.

Karl Wolf Biermann grew up as a communist and was strongly influenced by his father, his communist party, and his mother who worked against the Nazis. In 1953, when he was seventeen, he chose to move to East Germany to study philosophy and political science. He became an artist and figure of the oppositional reform movement whose poems and songs criticised the party and dictatorship of East Germany.
In 1976, while Biermann was on an authorized tour
he visited West Germany, which allowed the East German government
to deny reentry to East Germany and to deprive of citizenship.
His work was forbidden to be read and played in East Germany, and those who were discovered to be in possession of his poetry were persecuted.
Biermann did not stop accusing the government, criticizing the reality of life in East Germany, and satirizing West Germany’s contradiction as well.
Artists from around the world
in 1990 after the fall of the Berlin Wall
on Mühlenstrasse along the Spree river
created the East Side Gallery

on the east-facing side of the Berlin Wall. 107 paintings were completed to make a 1,316 meter long tributed mural of the Wall making it the world's longest and oldest outdoor art gallery, and today a monument of cultural heritage.
The East Side Gallery is a testament to the peaceful ideology that led to the resolution of the Berlin Wall and serves as a symbol not only for the German people, but also for the world.
The automobile manufacturer IndiKar
In November 2009
at the International Motor Show in Frankfurt, Germany
released the Trabant, once known as the national car of East Germany,
as a newly developed electric vehicle.

The revival of the Trabant marked the 20th anniversary of the collapse of the Berlin Wall. The iconic vehicle was known to all former East Germans by its nickname, “Trabi.” It was made of plastic, cotton, wood, and other obscure materials, and was known for its lightweight design and maximum speed of 60 mph. There are still many Trabi enthusiasts around the world. Through the “Trabi Rally” event and other social clubs surrounding the vehicle, the Trabi acts as a symbol for unified Germany and a reminder of their history.
The East German national football team
succeeded in advancing to the quarterfinals in 1974 at the 10th World Cup in West Germany.
At the finals held in Hamburg,

East Germany and West Germany were paired in the same group and played each other in the last qualification game of the round. Even though it was a game of minor importance, the world was watching the two nations clash for the first time.

East Germany scored the winning goal in the second half of the match and advanced to the quarterfinals. West Germany, by a positive point margin in the group round, made it through as well and ended up winning the World Cup. The West successfully regained its pride after its earlier loss.

It was the first time East and West Germany had both advanced to the final stage of the World Cup. Even after the West’s championship victory, they still felt the need to explain and apologize for their defeat against East Germany.
North Korean soldier, Ri Ho-jun
in 1972, won his country’s first gold medal in shooting
at the Munich Olympics in West Germany.
North Korea finished 22nd overall, taking home a total of five medals.
Ri Ho-jun set a world record in small-caliber shooting and spoke proudly of his accomplishment with a gold medal hanging from his neck, “I shot it thinking of shooting the heart of our enemy.”
Since the Cold War was in full swing and Ri Ho-jun was a soldier, the International Olympic Committee investigated his words and eventually received an apology.
The German national football team,
a year after the fall of the Berlin Wall in 1990,
at the FIFA World Cup in Italy
defeated Argentina to win the championship.
East and West Germans alike took to the streets to celebrate their victory with flags and car parades.
A shared passion for football and the international prestige of the World Cup forced Germans to appreciate the beauty of emotional harmony and a unified nation.
A single team composed of 52 male and 11 female athletes from East and West Germany
in January 1956,
competed at the Winter Olympics in Cortina d'Ampezzo, Italy.
It was the first time the two nations competed together on the international scene since the Second World War.
East and West Germany walked to Beethoven’s “Ode to Joy” and carried a united flag.

The International Olympic Committee (IOC) proposed that East Germany, a non-member nation, form a single team with West Germany to participate in the games. Negotiations for the plan to form a single team took about two years to finalize. This sportsmanship persisted for a handful years until the Tokyo Olympics in 1964, but by then the two had participated together a total of six times.
The unified women's ice hockey team of North and South Korea
played their first match against Switzerland at the 2018 Pyeongchang Olympic Games.
In attendance of the match at the Gwandong Hockey Center in Gangneung
were South Korean President Moon Jae-in, Vice Director of the WPK of North Korea, Kim Yo-jung, Swiss President Alain Berset, and President of the IOC, Thomas Bach.
This first game for the unified team drew a lot of attention, but the strong Swiss team easily defeated the Koreans.

Even though the two Koreas had walked together several times before at the opening ceremony, it was the first time they participated in the Olympic Games together. Regardless of their record at the games, their unifying presence captured the attention of the whole world.
The inter-Korean women’s singles table tennis team, represented by South Korea's Hyeon Jung-hwa and North Korea's Lee Bun-hee,
in 1991 at the 41st World Table Tennis Championship
held at the Jiba Convention Center in Japan, with all of Korea watching,
won the gold medal by defeating the Chinese, known at the time to be the strongest team in the world.
With China just four points shy of victory, North Korea's Yoo Soon-bok's quick backhand led to a thrilling win in the final point.
"Team Korea" came together as part of the inter-Korean reconciliation and exchange program of sports and took home the significant win to their respective countries after 47 years of division.
Olympic athletes of the East German National team
came in second overall at the Seoul Olympics.
East Germany’s success demonstrated their commitment to cultivating talent on a national level.

They organized more than 10,000 sport clubs nationwide and established physical education universities in all major cities. Every year, the government would admit three to four thousand students to the College of Physical Education and enroll them in master’s level programs in fields such as anatomy and biomechanics. To ensure international success, the East German government even condonded forms of doping.

The government also felt the need to strengthen its physical education policy to make up for the disadvantage of losing millions of people to the division, so much so that they included a clause in their constitution that demanded the need for sporting communities to cultivate a fully realized socialist personality.
The North and South Korean women’s football teams
played each other at the women’s Asian Cup quarterfinals on April 7th, 2017.
It was the 16th A-match and was held at the Kim Il-sung Stadium in Pyongyang.

The South Korean team had to defeat the North Koreans at home in order to the Asian Cup semi-finals and qualify for the World Cup. Meanwhile, the North Korean team was aiming to score multiple goals to secure a victory and a chance for the World Cup.
50,000 spectators crowded the stadium an hour before kickoff, anxiously awaiting the action.

North Korea came out on top in the first half, but the South Koreans responded with a goal in the second half, finishing the game in a tie. In total, the South Korean football team has 1 win, 3 draws, and 14 losses against the North Korean team.
The North and South Korean Olympic teams
on February 9, 2018 when the opening ceremony was held
at the Olympic Stadium in Pyeongchang, Gangwon Province of Korea,
after 11 years, made a joint entry at the opening ceremony of the games.
Several high-level inter-Korean talks took place to organize
and publicize the magnitude of this historic reconciliation.
Dorothea Ebert, who dreamed of becoming a violin soloist,
attempted her escape in 1983
on the Bulgarian and Yugoslavian border
but was arrested and extradited to East Germany and sentenced to two years and eight months in prison.
She tried to flee through Hungary and Romania to get to Bulgaria, but ultimately failed in her attempt to escape from the East German regime.

She found it increasingly difficult to accept the East German government’s intervention in her life. For example, despite her excellent academic record and talent, she was expected to become a music teacher, not a concert soloist. Fed up, she and her brother decided to flee, but were caught and persecuted. In December 1984, the West German government paid ransom for their release and allowed them to settle West Germany.
Kim Cheol-woong, a senior pianist of the North Korean National Symphonic Orchestra,
in October of 2001
fled through China to South Korea
leaving his life as an elite musician behind.

In North Korea, Mr. Kim was an established member of society, but in China he was only a lowly worker. His work was grueling and often put his hands in danger, but the thought of playing accompaniment piano in a church in South Korea drove him onward.

While studying in Moscow earlier in his life, Kim was exposed to various musical genres and composers who were banned in North Korea forcing him to realize the limitations of his own country. Back at home, while practicing Richard Clayderman's "A Comme Amour" as part of a proposal plan to his girlfriend, he was discovered by the North Korean State Political Security Department. Jazz music was banned in North Korea and Mr. Kim was forced to write an apology and explaning his actions. This incident motivated him to flee the country, as he could no longer endure the restrictions on the music he loved.
A 31-year-old building cleaner
in the early morning of April 19th, 1988
from Berlin-Treptow to the West Berlin district of Neukölln

surpassed the hinterland, or inner, wall on the East side of the border strip, and triggered the border signal zone alarm, but finally succeeded in climbing over the 3.6 meter high West Wall with the aid of his window cleaning ladder.
He somehow managed to evade each of the border guards 18 total shots
wielding only his window cleaning ladder.
An 18-year-old girl from Karl Marx Stadt, now Chemnitz
on July 7th, 1969
at the Drewitz border crossing in East Germany,
hid in the hollowed out belly of a dead cow
with the help of two escape aids who transported the fake beast in the back of a small truck.
The girl hoped to join her fiance in West Germany, but was discovered and moved to a prison camp. All three were sentenced, but the girl was eventually transferred to West Germany.
Two brothers who lived in the Klein Glienicke neighborhood of East Berlin
during the nights of July 25th and 26th, 1973
through a 19 meter self-built tunnel in the cellar of a building material warehouse
attempted to flee to West Berlin with their wives and five children.

Using only a children’s shovel and handless spade, the brothers transferred the dirt with a wood chipper up into the cellar. Their target was only 80 centimeters past the border on the West Berlin side. Unfortunately, a close relative of the family informed the East German secret police, the Stasi, of the family’s intention to flee.
The Stasi intervened immediately, but the families had already made it safely to the Marienfelde refugee center in West Berlin.
